sub_topic: Finding the maximum flow in a network.
message_1:
A company wants to transport goods from Node A to Node D in a network shown below. The maximum capacities of each edge are also given. What is the maximum amount of goods that can be transported from Node A to Node D?

```
      6
 A ------ B
 | \      |  \
 |   \10  |   \9
 |     \  |     \
 C-------D     E
     7      4
```
 
Write your answer in numerical form.
message_2:
To find the maximum flow in this network, we will use the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm. We will find augmenting paths and update the residual capacities until no more augmenting paths can be found.

1. Path A -> B -> D: Flow = 6 (minimum capacity along the path)
   Residual capacities:
   ```
   A --6/6--> B --6/9--> D
   A --0/10-> D
   A --0/7--> C --0/7--> D
   B --0/4--> E
   ```

2. Path A -> D: Flow = 4 (minimum capacity along the path)
   Residual capacities:
   ```
   A --6/6--> B --6/9--> D
   A --4/10-> D
   A --0/7--> C --0/7--> D
   B --0/4--> E
   ```

3. Path A -> C -> D: Flow = 7 (minimum capacity along the path)
   Residual capacities:
   ```
   A --6/6--> B --6/9--> D
   A --4/10-> D
   A --7/7--> C --7/7--> D
   B --0/4--> E
   ```

Now, there are no more augmenting paths from A to D. The maximum flow is the sum of the flows found in each step: 6 + 4 + 7 = 17.

So, the maximum amount of goods that can be transported from Node A to Node D is 17.
